All of Me.passage: All of Me is the debut studio album by American singer and songwriter Demi Lovato. It was released on September 9, 2010, through Hollywood Records. The album was written, composed, produced and recorded by various artists and producers. It features a duet with Joe Jonas on the title track, "Skyscraper", and a collaboration with Nick Jonas and the Jonas Brothers on "Give a Little Bit". The album also features a cover of "I Want You Back" by the Jackson 5, a cover of "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" by Tears for Fears, and a re-recording of Lovato's "Made in the USA". The album was preceded by the release of the lead single "Neon Lights", featuring Jonas, which reached number one on the US Hot 100, becoming Lovato's first number-one single and Jonas' second, and also reached number one in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.

Caracas.passage: Caracas (Spanish pronunciation: (kaɾaˈkas); also, Caraqui) is the capital and largest city of Venezuela. The city is located in the northern highlands of the country, on the northern banks of the Caracas River, which flows into the Caribbean Sea. The urban area of the city extends beyond the limits of the city proper into the adjacent municipalities of Libertador and Chacao, and the metropolitan area extends into the adjacent municipalities of El Hatillo and Sucre. The metropolitan area of Caracas is one of the largest urban agglomerations in the Americas, with an estimated population of around three million people. The city has been the center of political and economic power of Venezuela since the late 18th century, and it retains this position today.

El Salvador.passage: El Salvador (Spanish: "El Salvador" ), officially the Republic of El Salvador (Spanish: "República de El Salvador" ), is the smallest and the most densely populated country of Central America, located in the center of the region. It is bordered to the north by Honduras, to the south and west by Guatemala, to the east by the Pacific Ocean, and to the northeast by the country of Nicaragua.

qae_pairs.question: What is the country to the north of El Salvador?
qae_pairs.explanation: El Salvador is bordered to the north by Honduras.

qae_pairs.question: What is the country that borders El Salvador to the northeast?
qae_pairs.explanation: The country that borders El Salvador to the northeast is Nicaragua.

qae_pairs.question: What is El Salvador located in?
qae_pairs.explanation: El Salvador is located in Central America.

qae_pairs.question: Which country is to the west of El Salvador?
qae_pairs.explanation: The country of Guatemala is to the west of El Salvador.

the Federal Republic of Central America.term: the Federal Republic of Central America
the Federal Republic of Central America.passage: The Federal Republic of Central America (Spanish: "República Federal de Centroamérica" ) was a short-lived federal republic that existed in Central America from 1838 to 1842. It was formed by a group of liberal military officers who overthrew the conservative regime of General Francisco Morazán in 1838. The republic was established in the city of Jalapa, and its capital was the city of San Salvador. The republic was short-lived, however, and was overthrown by a conservative military coup in 1842.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Federal Republic of Central America was a short-lived federal republic that existed in Central America from 1838 to 1842.

John Milton.passage: John Milton (1608-1674) was an English poet and historian born in Bread Street, London. Milton was the second son of a middle-class family. His father was a vintner who died when Milton was eight. He was educated at St. Paul's School and Christ's College, Cambridge, where he was a pupil of John Owen. He became a Roman Catholic in his twenties. He was a Puritan who believed that the Church should be reformed and purified. He was a supporter of the Parliamentary cause in the English Civil War. He was a regicide and one of the judges at the trial of Charles I of England. He is considered one of the greatest English poets.

Identity.passage: In social sciences, social identity is a key concept in social psychology, social identity theory, and social cognitive theory. It is also used in the fields of organizational behavior and social psychology, and in cultural sociology. In sociology, social identification is a concept used to explain the formation of social groups, and how individuals and collectives define themselves in relation to others and to the environment. It is a key concept in the social psychology of Pierre Bourdieu and is also central to the work of Erving Goffman. Social identification is a key concept in the work on the social psychology of Henri Tajfel, who proposed the minimal-group paradigm. It is also used in the social identity model of collective behavior, which explains group behavior and intergroup relations. Social identification is used in social learning theory, a social psychological theory of learning that explains how people learn the norms, values and behaviors of their group. It is also used in self-categorization theory, which is a social psychological theory that explains how individuals form their self-concepts by categorizing themselves into groups. Social identification is also used in the social identity approach to cognition and the self, which is a psychological approach that proposes that the self is a social category.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of the person who proposed the social identity model of collective behavior?
qae_pairs.explanation: Henri Tajfel proposed the minimal-group paradigm.

ABC.passage: The American Broadcasting Company (ABC) is an American commercial broadcast television network that is owned by the Disney Media Networks division of The Walt Disney Company. The ABC Television Network, which is the oldest major broadcast network in the United States, is one of the Big Three television networks in terms of total audience, along with NBC and CBS. Owned by Disney, ABC's parent company, the network has its headquarters at the ABC Broadcast Center in Manhattan's West Side district. ABC's main corporate parent is Walt Disney Television, a subsidiary of Disney's Hollywood Studios division. ABC's origin dates back to the early 20th century radio network founded by electrical magnate Paul W. Disney, which later became known as the Walt Disney Company. The television network launched on April 19, 1941, as the first major broadcast network to be founded and owned by a major American corporation. The network has its primary headquarters in the Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, California. Its first president, Paul R. Heyl, was appointed in February 1945. ABC was originally composed of eight owned-and-operated and seven affiliated television stations, all operating out of ABC's facilities in New York. The television network gradually expanded to the West Coast, adding stations in Los Angeles and San Francisco in the late 1940s and then in Chicago and Philadelphia in the early 1950s.

qae_pairs.explanation: ABC started to expand to the West Coast in the early 1950s.

Smash Mouth.passage: "Smash Mouth is a pop band from San Jose, California, United States. The band consists of Greg Camp and Kevin Coleman, who are both former members of the bands The Greg Kihn Band and The Loud Family, as well as Coleman's brother, Steve Coleman, on bass and backing vocals.
